Distinguishing the flow of airborne microorganisms along with environmental conditions and their influence on historic heritage buildings
                    L. de-Lemos-Medina 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3795-73541,2, A. Bermúdez-Marín3, D. Jaikel-Víquez 
            ORCID: orcid.org/0000-0002-3553-53934,5,6, N. Camacho-Cambronero4, A. Segura-Vargas4, A. Gómez-Arrieta4, Y. Mora-Quirós5, K. Ureña-Alvarado7, L. Rautenberg8, I. Fonseca-Alfaro9,10, P. Calderón-Mesén5,11, M. Sandoval-Gutiérrez12, M. Redondo-Solano4,6,13 & …O. A. Herrera-Sancho

Subjects
        
            Air microbiologyCharacterization and analytical techniquesEnvironmental healthEnvironmental impactEnvironmental monitoring

AbstractThe National Theater of Costa Rica is a national symbol of our country and an important architectural landmark. It was built in 1897 and is decorated with large-format paintings made by Italian artists. One of these painters was Paolo Serra, who was in charge of decorating three chambers, including the Management’s Office (MO). A yearly volumetric air sampling was conducted in seven rooms of the theater, showing high levels of circulating fungal spores in the MO. Thus, further analysis was carried out in this venue. First, the environmental conditions (wind velocity, temperature, relative humidity, and particles) were monitored. Then, the air and particles’ flow and the probability of particles concentration were simulated for different scenarios of natural ventilation using a Discrete Phase Model. This allowed us to identify areas where damage and microorganisms were probably more prevalent. The artworks in this chamber were analyzed to determine the types of damages identified: buckling, cracks, cuts, craquelure, holes, scratches, color gaps with exposed fabric or wall, insect debris, flaking, humidity stains, interventions of old restorations, opaque stains, whitish stains and total loss of the original image. As a complement, a microbiological sample was held in 34 sites of interest, resulting in the isolation and identification of five bacterial isolates and thirteen fungi. We identified the artist’s main colour palette: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine and natural barite. We can conclude that artworks under non-controlled environmental conditions may present a significant degree of deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration.

                        IntroductionCultural historical buildings represent a form of expression which frames certain feelings and describes the social and economical state of societies within a given moment. It is necessary to preserve these constructions for the next generation because of their great historical value, which allows us to understand various aspects of societies, such as their history and development. These cultural heritage conservation processes are supported by a series of problem-solving perspectives and tools that allow the identification of materials and considerations from the point of view of technique and technology used by artists for their intentions and creative process1,2,3,4,5. Little is known about the environmental impact of geographical location on heritage buildings, especially of those located in tropical countries, along with the intention of its construction and it is not clear what factors represent a key challenge to ensure the conservation of the artworks in these atmospheres.Therefore, this pilot study seeks to remedy these challenges by analyzing the environmental conditions of the Management’s Office (MO) of the National Theater of Costa Rica (NTCR [built in 1891-1897]) and to determine their impact on the large-format paintings located within this chamber (see Fig. 1 for our artistic visualization). The NTCR is a historical building that represents society’s desire to experience various expressions of art locally, like other theaters’ intent throughout Europe and Latin America6. In this building, the south and east sides are lined with typically busy streets (pedestrians and vehicles), while the north and west sides have a plaza where many pigeons live and where people pass through all day long. The MO is located in the southwest corner of the building (Fig. 2) and is decorated with wall-to-wall murals and a large-format oil painting on the ceiling, all painted by Italian artist Paolo Serra. Environmental conditions play an important role in the maintenance of these historic buildings, especially those that shelter important artworks that are exposed to climate changes and different conditions since the time of its construction7,8. Therefore, environmental conditions could be a major factor, causing degradation damage to historic heritage if there are no climatized systems that keep the temperature and relative humidity under control, independently of the external conditions. Another important practical implication is that when the historic buildings are open to the public, there are greater probabilities that the temperature, humidity, airborne microorganisms, internal microclimate, and the energy performance of the entire system will vary8.To a limited extent, three methods have been identified as being potentially important for keeping the internal environmental conditions of historic buildings under control: (1) natural ventilation, (2) forced ventilation and (3) air conditioning. Most historic buildings were designed and built using natural ventilation (1), accordingly, it is an additional challenge to make modifications that allow the inclusion of any of the other types of techniques, namely (2) and (3), especially in those that contain cultural heritage without causing structural harm or several major drawbacks to the artworks9. It has been shown that there is an unambiguous relationship between temperature variations and paintings, specifically thermal fatigue could be generated, which has possible connections to the artworks’ damages10. It is worth mentioning that the NTCR only has an air conditioning system in the main chamber, yet the rest of the rooms do not have controlled environmental conditions. The MO chamber has three large windows that are periodically opened. The artworks are not exposed to the public, except for special visitors with controlled access, including diplomats, researchers, conservators, restorers, and visitors by appointment or formal invitation. The access door to this room is located on the north side, next to the main entrance of the building. Once inside, one can appreciate the large format paintings that delicately decorate all the walls and ceiling of the chamber. The study’s objective was to examine these large-format paintings exhibited under non-controlled environmental conditions from an interdisciplinary viewpoint for evidence findings that methodically assess the conservation state, i.e. the deterioration and biodeterioration, chromatic alteration, and the artist’s color palette (Fig. 1). Finally, our aim is therefore to provide a systematic correlation between these parameters and deterioration that can be identified in the artworks. It is worth mentioning that in previous works at the NTCR, we observed a new fungal species associated with damaging cultural heritage11: we distinguished particular fluorescent areas which were recognized through its red-coral fluorescence as Madder Lake12, we identified Carlo Ferrario’s main colour palette, along with we successfully achieved the characterization of eight genera of calcareous nannofossils found in the ground layers of his artwork13. Carlo Ferrario was an Italian artist, who was commissioned to paint Musas I and Musas II, two of the most important and representative paintings of the NTCR. There are variations in the painter’s signatures: in some of the works at the NTCR, he signed as Paolo, while in others he used the name Pablo. This could be due to an adaptation to the Latin American context of the time or, perhaps, to the fact that one of his assistants signed on his behalf, a common practice at that time. The deterioration mechanism described by Savkovic28 and collaborators indicates that the fungus can cause surface deterioration, causing brown discoloration stains, or even deep penetrating the artwork, surpassing the layer of paint and reaching the support. This is achieved through mechanical activities, such as the penetration of hyphae that increases the internal pressure of the painting leading to the formation of cracks. In addition, it causes damage through the chemical activity of extracellular enzymes secreted by the fungus when trying to use paint components as a source of nutrients. The elemental composition of the region of interest of the cross-section was identified by SEM-EDX48, see Fig. 6A.5, in order to determine the average size of each pigment and conduct the first ever study on Serra’s palette. Table 5 presents an overview of the particle size along with the complex morphology of each material used which allow us, based on evidence, to suggest that the ultramarine pigment and barite is from a natural origin. We hypothesize that the ground contains mainly barite, lead white pigment all mixed with traces of calcium carbonate. The last column includes the main elements for every type of pigment.Full size tableConclusionsThese research aimed to examine for the first time Serra’s paintings under non-controlled environmental conditions in a historic heritage building. It methodically assesses the deterioration, biodeterioration, and chromatic alteration, along with the artist’s color palette. One of the most significant outcomes of this cutting-edge multidisciplinary research, assembled by our fluid simulation using solid particle dynamics in the environment chamber along with experimental data of wind speed, temperature, and particle size, among others, was the recognition of specific zones, at the artworks, which could be affected by their visual appearance over the time since the painting’s creation. The second major finding to emerge was that following the regions of interest previously obtained, we identified a considerable amount of deterioration patterns, biodeterioration microorganisms, and degradation of colour in the paintings. This finding has important suggestions for establishing affordable, compact, efficient, accessible, and novel non-destructive techniques, especially in the extreme climate and humidity of the tropics in Latin America in historic heritage buildings. The third significant finding of this investigation was that in an exploratory experiment we recognized the main artist’s colour palette, which includes: madder lake, lead white, calcium carbonate, yellow ocher, natural ultramarine, and natural barite. There is abundant room for further progress in determining the stratigraphic’s internal nature of the degradation of colour discovered in the outer green layers of the painting.MethodsPiece of study and characteristicsThe artwork of the ceiling (Danthe and Raphael) in the MO of the NTCR is made with the marouflage technique, which consists of adhering manufactured artworks on a flexible support to a more rigid support. Due to its large dimensions, the support was made with tongue and groove joint wood. On the other hand, the mural was made on a brick support covered with stucco, the same material used in the construction of the NTCR building6,14.According to the information given by the administration of the NTCR and the observation, during approximately 1998 there was a restoration of the artworks in this room. Specifically for the murals they did a reintegration of the colour and improved the support of the mural. In the case of the ceiling, there is no documental, experienced, or physical evidence of a restoration. The administration has established some preventive conservation, which includes restricted public access inside the room and natural ventilation during some days of the week51.Multispectral imagingWe generated visible (VIS) and ultraviolet (UV) photographs based on the procedure described by our previous investigations12,13. Briefly, photographs were acquired using a Nikon D5300 camera with an AF-S DX Micro-NIKKOR 40mm f/2.8G lens, and was adjusted in order to obtain high resolution photos (24 megapixels). A white balance was carried out for all the photographs 52 and a pigment reference named Cultural Heritage Open Source Pigments Checker (CHSOS) pigment reference was used.Aerial fungal contamination of the NTCRThe fungal contamination of seven rooms of the NTCR was determined by measuring the concentration of aerial fungal spores via an active sampling. The former names of the sampled areas were Hall next to the Ladies’ Cafeteria, Men”s Canteen, Hall next to the Men’s Canteen, NTCR Management Office, Smoking Lounge for Ladies, Smoking Lounge for Men, and the Presidential Teather Box (see Supplementary Figure S1). These locations were selected because large format paintings are found there . A Burkard Personal Volumetric Air Sampler (Burkard Manufacturing Co. Ltd., United Kingdom) was used to collect the airborne spore particles53. The samples were collected on the last Friday of every month, for a year, starting in January 2022 (except in June and December because the NTCR was closed on said dates due to a hurricane and holidays, respectively). The instrument operates at a nominal air throughput of 10 liters per minute and deposits them onto a glass slide covered by a thin layer of Vaseline or petroleum gel. The spores obtained through the layer of Vaseline, were counted and identified using a light microscope Olympus CX31 (Olympus Life Science, Waltham, MA, USA) at 400 X. Identification of species and groups of interest was done using the atlas “Aeroallergen Identification” (American College of Allergy and Immunology, University of Michigan, November 10th, 1999). The significant differences between the spore concentration by month were determined using a one-way ANOVA test with a Post Hoc Tukey. Statistical significance was defined using a p value less than 0.05. Ltd. was used (see description in the Aerial fungal contamination of the NTCR). Sampling sites were previously selected by an expert artist criterion: ten sampling sites from the murals and 24 from the ceiling painting. (Supplementary Figure S2). In accordance, in this model, the entrance flow is the particle flow entering through the south (or west) windows and the particles created in the room, which are assumed to be zero. The sedimentation terminal speed, \(V_{s}\), can be calculated with the Stokes law, as the particle’s size D are between 1 \({\upmu }\)m to 10 \({\upmu }\)m, given by:$$\begin{aligned} V_{s} = gD^{2}(\frac{\rho _{p}-\rho _{air}}{18\mu }), \end{aligned}$$

Initially, they were examined using a stereoscope for macro photography. For microanalysis, each sample was mounted on a metal base and secured with double-sided carbon tape.
